texts.definition: Diegetic objects in game worlds that can be carried or interacted with.
markups: <style="Definition">Diegetic objects in game worlds that can be carried or interacted with.</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are objects in game worlds that players can picked up and carried by players' avatars or units. They can affect actions and attributes,  and acquiring them or moving them to specific locations may be required to complete goals.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> play larger roles in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20and%20Dragons">Dungeons and Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, both as rewards and as ways of making player characters better. One evidence of their role is the fact that entire supplements or sourcebooks are dedicated to them<ref name="lt"/><ref name="ht"/><ref name="ut"/><ref name="bt"/><ref name="vault"/><ref name="vault2"/>.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">LARPs</link></style> also put much emphasis on <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>. For games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/1942%20%E2%80%93%20Noen%20%C3%A5%20stole%20p%C3%A5">1942 – Noen å stole på</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragonbane">Dragonbane</link></style>, players need to put considerable effort and skill into producing the physical items and props that are to be used during the gaming events.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Adventure%20Games">Adventure Games</link></style>, e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork series</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maniac%20Mansion">Maniac Mansion</link></style>, have much of their gameplay structured around the location of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> that then need to be used in specific places and context to advance in the games. Other computer games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style> can contain large amounts of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>, mostly created by the players themselves.

For game examples of more specific types of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>, see the patterns <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are a type of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> which differentiates itself from other <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> by each individual unit having its own identity and presence. General categories of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> include <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style> for protecting against <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> for providing <style="Link"><link="improved-abilities">Improved</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> for modifying <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style>. The presence of <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> in a game (as <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> or not) also opens up for <style="Link"><link="ammunition">Ammunition</link></style> to be <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>. These are all <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> but <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> providing passive benefits are other examples of <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>. While these all provide or modify some gameplay functionality, <style="Link"><link="cosmetic-game-items">Cosmetic Game Items</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> are examples of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> that can serve purposes in games without directly affecting gameplay - all other type of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can also be modulated by being <style="Link"><link="cosmetic-game-items">Cosmetic Game Items</link></style> as well. <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> provide gameplay functionality but are instead only weakly present as <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> since coming in contact with them removes them from <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.

There are some general considerations of how <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> should be modeled in a game. First, not all <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> may be able to interact with specific <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>, giving those that can do so <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style> and changing the usefulness and value of the <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>. They can have many various <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style> of which the most common are probably ''value'' (which makes all <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> to a common type of <style="Link"><link="resources">Resource</link></style>) and ''weight''. Another is if they should be <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style> through <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>; this is most common for <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>. Not all <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> have tangible presences in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> (this is common for <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> for example); those that do are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>.

One aspect of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> is how they should be acquired. While some <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can be <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, e.g. after achieved <style="Link"><link="achievements">Achievements</link></style> or completing <style="Link"><link="quests">Quests</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can also be <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, i.e. existing as game elements in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> before being acquired, possible through appearing as <style="Link"><link="loot">Loot</link></style>. In this case, a vital design decision is in what locations the <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> should appear, and if later new instances should appear there as well, and if so, if they do so through <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style> with other players, <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>, or at <style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>, make it possible to make the acquisition of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> into <style="Link"><link="trade-offs">Trade-Offs</link></style> between these items and other <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> or <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>. Another option is that the players can construct <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> themselves through <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, as for example done in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style>. A final option, related to <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, is that the players create the items as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-actions">Extra-Game Actions</link></style>. These <style="Link"><link="player-created-game-elements">Player Created Game Elements</link></style> are most commonly found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">LARPs</link></style> but can also be found in text-based MUDs (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/DragonMud">DragonMud</link></style>) where players can create the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can be used as goal objects in <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> goals, especially if there is only one instance of a <style="CurrentLink">Game Item</style> available and it is in a predetermined place. Once players can have <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>, other design options open up. <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style> allow for many <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> to be carried and interacted with through <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>. Having <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> lets players choose which <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> should be active or should provide <style="Link"><link="new-abilities">New Abilities</link></style> at any given point in time. <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> can be used to allow <style="Link"><link="combos">Combos</link></style> to occur for having specific combinations of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> equipped, and acquiring such <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style> can be

For <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> one can consider if <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are to be <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style>, and if so how this is controlled. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> is one option here, which adds <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style> to those game elements holding them as well as <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> and possibly <style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>. Otherwise, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> may simply be that no offensive <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> actions such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> are possible but those holding <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> can either drop them or voluntary engage in <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>. Some games that wishes to regulate <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style>, make the picking up, using, or equipping of them activate an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enforced%20Ownership">Enforced Ownership</link></style> - note that this does not have to completely make transfers impossible, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> for example lets "soulbound" <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> be sold to <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>/<style="Link"><link="self-service-kiosks">Self-Service Kiosks</link></style>.

The creation of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> in games with <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style> needs additional design consideration compared to other types of games since these may become focus of <style="Link"><link="game-element-trading">Game Element Trading</link></style> and since designers can make them into <style="Link"><link="purchasable-game-advantages">Purchasable Game Advantages</link></style>.

A special case of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are those that trigger <style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style> when picked up or equipped; these are <style="Link"><link="traps">Traps</link></style> which also often give <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Surprises">Surprises</link></style> since they are typically designed to look like other harmless <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> is a diegetic pattern but <style="Link"><link="alien-space-bats">Alien Space Bats</link></style> may be used to introduce (at least initially) non-thematic <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>, as for example the alien blasters in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style>.

Players' willingness to interact repeatedly on a basic level with <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can be increased by providing <style="Link"><link="clickability">Clickability</link></style>. A special case of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are those who have significant physical presence and may not be representations of something but actually be the things themselves. Although these are "modified" by being physical objects, from a gameplay perspective this can be seen as modifying the <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> through <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="player-artifact-proximity">Player-Artifact Proximity</link></style>.

Most types of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can be used both in <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style> generally and intentionally in <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, but <style="Link"><link="macguffins">MacGuffins</link></style> are ones specifically used for this. While they can be moved about, <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can provide <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style> since they can contain recollections, notes, images, etc., that can help tell what happened in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> earlier.

As mentioned above, <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>. When they exist as objects in <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, their positions are <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="spawn-points">Spawn Points</link></style> if they are replenished through <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>. While the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> can help create a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> they are also modulated by this in how they can be presented.

When <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style> of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> is regulated the existence of them open up for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Transfer%20of%20Control">Transfer of Control</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style> actions to achieve <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="collections">Collection</link></style> goals. This may also open up for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competitions">Competitions</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style> if the location of the <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are known to the players. However, it may or may not be possible to drop or trade <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> after it has been taken. If <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are dropped when <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> carrying them are killed or destroyed, or if <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style> over other players <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are supported in the game design, the presence of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> promotes <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style> even after they have been acquired. Being able to drop <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> gives players the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to construct their own <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>. If players do not have synchronized play or game sessions, the change of ownership of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> in principle becomes <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style> goals can be created by designating places where <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are to be moved to (this can automatically trigger the success or require players to intentionally drop the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Game%20Item">Game Items</link></style> there).

Several types of <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style>, especially <style="Link"><link="armor">Armor</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> but also <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style>, offers a form of <style="Link"><link="character-development">Character Development</link></style> for games with <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (and for <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> the presence of <style="Link"><link="player-character-skill-composites">Player/Character Skill Composites</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style> can easily arise in such games, or games where individual <style="CurrentLink">Game Items</style> are in other ways valuable, if they can be lost in some way (e.g. through <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style>).

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Competition">Competition</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deliver">Deliver</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-storytelling">Environmental Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="gain-ownership">Gain Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="heterogeneous-game-element-ownership">Heterogeneous Game Element Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="narration-structures">Narration Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="races">Races</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="actions-have-diegetically-social-consequences">Actions Have Diegetically Social Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="attention-demanding-gameplay">Attention Demanding Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tension">Tension</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="ability-losses">Ability Losses</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="artifact-location-proximity">Artifact-Location Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Attributes">Attributes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="clickability">Clickability</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collecting">Collecting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="collections">Collections</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="converters">Converters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="cosmetic-game-items">Cosmetic Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="decreased-abilities">Decreased Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="destructible-objects">Destructible Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-tangible-game-items">Diegetically Tangible Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Enforced%20Ownership">Enforced Ownership</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="persistent-game-worlds">Persistent Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="player-artifact-proximity">Player-Artifact Proximity</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="privileged-abilities">Privileged Abilities</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Resource%20Generators">Resource Generators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="rewards">Rewards</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="sets">Sets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="spawning">Spawning</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>,
